bibl.title: The Vitality of Egyptian Images in Late Antiquity: Christian Memory and Response.
bibl.note: From the late IVth to later centuries, the traditional Egyptian divine images continued to be regarded with a sense of potency and sacred presence, something to be protected for the well-being of family and community, or something to be mutilated.

bibl.title: The Sculptural Environment of the Roman Near East. Reflections on Culture, Ideology, and Power

bibl.seg: FRANKFURTER David, The Vitality of Egyptian Images in Late Antiquity: Christian Memory and Response.

Yaron Z. ELIAV, Elise A. FRIEDLAND and Sharon HERBERT (Edd.), The Sculptural Environment of the Roman Near East. Reflections on Culture, Ideology, and Power = Interdisciplinary Studies in Ancient Culture and Religion. 9 (Leuven-Dudley, MA, 2008) pp. 659-678, 2 pll.

From the late IVth to later centuries, the traditional Egyptian divine images continued to be regarded with a sense of potency and sacred presence, something to be protected for the well-being of family and community, or something to be mutilated.
